title: Austin Levi Fraser
text:
Austin Levi Fraser (March 17, 1868 – April 22, 1946) was a <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> lawyer, judge and political figure on <a href="Prince%20Edward%20Island">Prince Edward Island</a>. He represented <a href="1st%20Kings">1st Kings</a> in the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Prince%20Edward%20Island">Legislative Assembly of Prince Edward Island</a> from 1904 to 1908 and <a href="King%27s%20%28Prince%20Edward%20Island%20electoral%20district%29">King's</a> in the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20Canada">House of Commons of Canada</a> from 1908 to 1911 as a <a href="Conservative%20Party%20of%20Canada%20%28historical%29">Conservative</a> member.
He was born in <a href="Vernon%20River%2C%20Prince%20Edward%20Island">Vernon River, Prince Edward Island</a>, the son of Edward F. Fraser and Florence MacIsaac, and was educated at <a href="Prince%20of%20Wales%20College">Prince of Wales College</a> and <a href="Saint%20Dunstan%27s%20University">Saint Dunstan's College</a>. He taught school for several years, then studied law in the office of <a href="Francis%20Haszard">Francis Haszard</a> and was admitted to the bar in 1900. In 1901, he married Maud Adelaide Moar and set up practice in <a href="Souris%2C%20Prince%20Edward%20Island">Souris</a>. Fraser resigned his seat in the provincial assembly in 1908 to run for a seat in the House of Commons. He was defeated by <a href="James%20Joseph%20Hughes">James Joseph Hughes</a> when he ran for reelection in 1911. He was then named judge in the court for <a href="Kings%20County%2C%20Prince%20Edward%20Island">Kings County</a>. Fraser died in Souris at the age of 78.
